309.00.text: And actually, this work was done in the 1960s

312.00.text: by a famous biologist named Malcolm Burrows.

317.00.text: what's called a "catch mechanism," or "click mechanism."

320.00.text: And what this basically consists of is a large muscle

324.00.text: that takes a good long time to contract,

326.00.text: and a latch that prevents anything from moving.

329.00.text: So the muscle contracts, and nothing happens.

331.00.text: And once the muscle's contracted completely, everything's stored up --

334.00.text: the latch flies upward, and you've got the movement.

338.00.text: And that's basically what's called a "power amplification system."

341.00.text: It takes a long time for the muscle to contract,

343.00.text: and a very short time for the limb to fly out.

447.00.text: The saddle-shaped structure is also known as a "hyperbolic paraboloid surface,"

454.00.text: And this is very well known to engineers and architects,

456.00.text: because it's a very strong surface in compression.

459.00.text: It has curves in two directions,

461.00.text: one curve upward and opposite transverse curve down the other,

464.00.text: so any kind of perturbation spreads the forces

467.00.text: over the surface of this type of shape.

470.00.text: So it's very well known to engineers, not as well known to biologists.

474.00.text: It's also known to quite a few people who make jewelry,

478.00.text: because it requires very little material

481.00.text: to build this type of surface, and it's very strong.

484.00.text: So if you're going to build a thin gold structure,

486.00.text: it's very nice to have it in a shape that's strong.

488.00.text: Now, it's also known to architects. One of the most famous architects

493.00.text: is Eduardo Catalano, who popularized this structure.

496.00.text: And what's shown here is a saddle-shaped roof that he built

499.00.text: that's 87 and a half feet spanwise.

503.00.text: It's two and a half inches thick, and supported at two points.

506.00.text: And one of the reasons why he designed roofs this way is because it's --

511.00.text: he found it fascinating that you could build such a strong structure

515.00.text: that's made of so few materials and can be supported by so few points.

519.00.text: And all of these are the same principles that apply

523.00.text: to the saddle-shaped spring in stomatopods.

525.00.text: In biological systems it's important not to have a whole lot

528.00.text: of extra material requirements for building it.
